content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem itself is excellent, and finding a solution is both non-trivial and very satisfying. The statement is clearly written, and the graphics cover everything necessary.

I used a combination of heuristics and recursive backtracking; no pathfinding was required. C++ managed to brute-force the solution, but I wasnâ€™t as lucky when trying to brute-force it in Kotlin.
Some non-blocking recommendations:

1. Each testcase should have exactly one matching validator, whether by flipping, mirroring, or rotating the board. Yours are a bit random. I failed some validators in both parts while passing all testcases, which can be a bit discouraging.

2. I would probably highlight only a single cell in case of hitting an intersection.
My over-engineered solution for Part 1 score 96% in Part 2 without changes and it fails only in "larger sparse 3" test/val.  I'll dig into this puzzle to find some clues.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Just like Part 1, I am generating all possible paths between each set of endpoints and then finding a combination that works to cover the entire board. I found this approach very difficult to do in Python considering the time limit.

In the end, I was surprised how nicely Part 1 and Part 2 work together. The test case design is excellent. This second part was a wonderful challenge! Well done!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Usually part 2 add more rules/constraints here it's the opposite, all that's left are the colors, meaning the number of possible path explodes.
Lots of tests/validator to cover everything and challenge your algorithm into timeout.

Slightly altered error messages and also changed the black colour to a gray for easier viewing.

Update: Adding an updated link to part 1.
Update 2: Fixed circular bug found from part 1.
Ok for me! Ready to go!
Ok for me! Ready to go!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Updated title to "Part 2" as an easier version is being created for "Part 1".

Updated the images from imgur due to inaccessibility in the UK.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I am stuck on the 4 Large Sparse test cases. Test Case 18 seems quite different to me from the other 3 in that it is not easily divided into rectangular sections that can be solved independently of the bigger puzzle. For the other 3, it seem I can break the grid into rectangles that can be solved independently. Test case #18 looks like it needs a completely unique strategy.

If there is some specific logic strategy that solves the sparse test cases, I wonder if more sparse test cases are needed to make sure the user doesn't splice something together like I'm hoping to do.
Hmm ... Isn't that another mission for AlgorithmX ?

Congratulations on drafting your first puzzle contribution using the CodinGame SDK! ðŸŽ‰

Your question 2
* 'Unsure if "incorrect paths" should be displayed or not': are you referring to the console or the viewer? In either case, could you clarify the scenarios you're considering?

Rules
* Please specify the location of the origin (0, 0), and indicate the directions which the x- and y-coordinates increase.

Loss Conditions
* Consider reordering the points to match the order in which the loss conditions are checked: "Responseâ€¦", "Theâ€¦", "Attemptedâ€¦" and "Numberâ€¦".

Output
* Please change the heading to "Output per turn".

* Please change "first coordinate" to "first tile".

* Please change "second coordinate" to "second tile".

* Please state that each section of the path must be strictly horizontal or vertical.

  (i.e. either [[x1]] = [[x2]] or [[y1]] = [[y2]])

Your question 1
* Unsure on the limits for turns / time limits: Have you tested your solution to verify that it's possible to solve all cases within the current time limits? This should serve as the initial basis. We'll also need feedback from other CodinGamers to determine whether the limits feel too loose, just right, or too tight.

Example
* Please add "3 3" as the first line of the input.

* (optional) You could embed an image (e.g. of a grid showing the coordinates and the solution) here if it helps illustrate the example.

Default stub
* The order of the variables in the default output line differs from the one stated in Output section.

Error messages
* "Invalid colour identifier number": Consider deleting the word "number" for consistency with Output section.

* "Same input or not straight line": Would it be more precise to say "point" instead of "input"?

Viewer
* One path segment was missing in the viewer after I passed the case "Around the World": https://imgur.com/a/9HqUz81 . Here's the solution I used:

h, w = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for i in range(h):
    row = input()
solution = """1 0 0 0 1
1 2 2 2 2
0 0 0 3 1
3 0 3 3 1
0 3 3 3 1
1 0 1 1 1
2 0 2 1 1
3 0 2 0 1""".splitlines()
for line in solution:
    print(line)

Cases
* Look good, except that the "Large" cases aren't really that large? I'll probably examine the cases more closely later.

Thanks.

P.S. Yay, I found the Easter egg too! ðŸ¤£
Found an Easter egg
Thought it might go a bit longer without being found but apparently not... Hope you enjoyed ðŸ™‚

Thanks ðŸ˜‡ Many points to brush up on! 

Key responses:

* Question 1 time - I've done in java and python and both work fine with current time restraints - I've not tested to find the actual execution time of them but was more a general question due to other languages - My understanding is there is a variable time limit for different languages in regular puzzles - so wondering how I work out a good rule for setting a single time limit for all.

* Question 1 turn limit - Technically with the tight loss conditions not allowing "invalid paths" the turn limit is h*w - (no. of start_tiles / 2) - The only thing that will change that if allowing for creation of the same path/link multiple times or allow for changing the colour of links/paths. I guess the question refers to Q2 also about allowing invalid moves or removing mention of turn limit as it can't be reached / setting it to a variable based on the equation above.
edit: Alternatively I could set the limit to be h*w -  (no. of start_tiles / 2) - 1 which would force the user to have at least 1 path connecting more than 2 tiles.

* Question 2 - I mean in terms of visuals - adding a connector even if the output is invalid (e.g. connecting wrong colour to a 'start node' or crossing over) Suppose it would help with debugging but is also a bit ugly - https://imgur.com/a/BB2i0mR

* Viewer - That wasn't actually visual, that was a bug in the end game function thinking those were connected... Should be fixed now.

* Cases - Originally were 7x7, which isn't large but computationally is a lot larger but I decided that 6x6 is probably a good limit. I could/will test dense 7x7s to see how bad they actually are though.

* Error messages and case names were just testing/low effort - Just wanted to get the puzzle out there for others to test / comment on ðŸ˜ƒ

Hope you enjoyed finding the egg ðŸ˜‚
Thanks for your comments, as always!

Did I see "logical puzzle" in the first sentence???

Outstanding job on the puzzle @Harry.B. Great test case design! I cannot solve the big grids with Algorithm X alone. I will need some logical problem-space reduction and just thinking about how to do that has been super fun this morning!

I can now solve everything except test cases 18 and 35. Getting to this point has not been a "medium" difficulty experience for me. Maybe I'm doing something wrong, but really minimizing the number of legitimate paths has been brutal (in a fun sort of way ðŸ™‚).

I can add a 'janky' assumption like you mentioned in the comments below and solve all test cases. Are you able to solve all test cases in Python without any jankiness now?

Glad you've been enjoying it and thank you for testing it! ðŸ™‚

* I have not attempted to write an non-janky version as of yet but I will attempt a backtracking approach that may work. - Is your current approach only using that Algorithm-X (I've not seen anything about that...sorry) with your optimizations or have you tried anything else?
** My current approach is a bunch of extentions from the original problem that included only small dense puzzles which did not require all the tiles be used - So not efficient but works with the optim.

* I'm never sure on difficulty, I'll leave medium as a placeholder for now and see what others have to say.

* Side note: Have you used the debug mode and/or found any bugs with the viewer?

Yes, I do use Algorithm X for the backtracking. I have now settled on a heuristic that I feel confident would "probably" work on any test case. I still have a few more ideas to play around with in the hopes of having a solution that doesn't use a heuristic for the sparse test cases.

I wonder if this puzzle would be a good candidate for a Part I and  Part II. Nothing changes on your end except test cases:

Part I - Medium - backtracking
Part II - Hard - backtracking + significant optimization

I really like the visuals you get by making this a solo game. The downside is that all languages get the same time limit. If you were to break the puzzle into 2 parts, I'm not sure how different those two parts would be for the fast languages.

I used debug mode extensively yesterday while I was optimizing my path generation algorithm. I have not found any bugs with the viewer.

I've never been a big fan of puzzles split into two parts based solely on case difficulty when the rules stay the same ðŸ˜›. To be clear, having easier cases in part 1 and harder cases in part 2 is totally fine, but I'd love to see new rules introduced as well, like in Rummikub parts 1 and 2: https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/rummikub-1 and https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/rummikub-2 .

If the author is considering a part 2 of this puzzle, one idea I'd suggest is adding tunnels that allow two paths to intersect. Here's an example of that mechanic from the adventure game "The Legacy 2": https://imgur.com/a/PYoSW70

What do you think?

I don't think there is any way to combine CG's Nonogram with 5x5, 16x16 and Multisize. I wouldn't want to eliminate String Balls I and just have String Balls 2. In both cases, no new rules have been introduced. However, the algorithm used to solve the easier version will not solve the harder version. How about Mars Lander 2 vs 3?

I'm kind of a fan of the multi-step puzzle family. My experience as been that I am forced to learn new things to solve each new puzzle.

I really like the tunnels idea!

Nonogram: did you mean Codewars instead of CG?

In CG, the maximum number of test cases for puzzles without a viewer is 25 pairs. I believe it's even higher for viewer-enabled puzzles? In both types of puzzles, it's entirely possible to include cases of increasing difficulty within a single puzzle, without needing to split it into multiple parts when the rules stay the same.

As I mentioned earlier, "Rummikub" is a great example. Its split into two parts is justified by the shear number of test cases, which wouldn't fit into a single puzzle. It's also thoughtfully designed, gradually introducing new rules and scenarios. This aligns well with your idea of a "multi-step" puzzle: something that can absolutely be achieved within a single puzzle when done well.

With that in mind, I don't really see why "Takuzu Solver" needs to be in 2 parts, or why "Mars Lander" parts 2 and 3 are separate. The same goes for "The hungry duck": the author claims that players don't have to care about timeouts in part 1 while they do in part 2, but I was able to solve both with the same solution.

That said, it's perfectly ok for us to have different views on this ðŸ˜‰. I'm also glad to hear that you like the tunnels idea. If that (or other rule variations) is introduced in part 2, I'd fully support splitting "Connect the Colours" into two parts.
I just looked up "The Hungry Duck". I got 100 XP in less than 5 minutes of coding. I agree that no matter how hungry that duck is, it should not have been two puzzles.

* I've added 4 extra sparse test/validators and changed the order so they're more similar pairs. Let me know how your solution gets on with them!

* In terms of part 2 - Once / if this puzzle is finished and accepted (ðŸ¤ž) A few ideas to add to the tunnels suggestion: blockers - breakable blocks - already drawn connections - could be a nice continuation.

* Also changed the difficulty to 'Hard'

re: new test cases

New test cases are very nice! I had to come up with a new heuristic strategy. Once I had a strategy that worked for all test cases, it also worked for all validators.

@Timinator, as you've already implemented a solution, could you please take a look at the ordering of the cases? For example, it seems like the "Single Path" test/validator should appear earlier. Thanks.

Single path I put it where it was as I felt it fits with the single colour test. They should be the other way around anyway if it stays with it.

Failing that I could move it down to test/validator 4 just before the all colour tests, which I think will also work.

I spent very little time with either of those test cases - single path / single color. Single path does feel out of place where it is. I like your idea of moving it up.

I spent quite a bit of time with all the other test cases and I feel like the progression is good.

I don't know the input-reading duration, but the time limit for producing the output is measured starting from the moment you finish reading the input, lasting approximately the duration you've set in the referee. You can verify this with a simple code like the one below:

import sys
from time import perf_counter

t0 = perf_counter()
h, w = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for i in range(h):
    row = input()
t1 = perf_counter()

print(t1 - t0, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

t2 = t1
while t2 - t1 < 1.95: # you may change 1.95 to other values for testing
    t2 = perf_counter()

print(t2 - t1, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
And oh, better to print a valid output at the end to distinguish between a real timeout and not outputting anything.

Seems to be ~4s for the input and then, as you say, around the 2s mark where it gets the timeout. 

Also I've included 3 8x8's at the end as validators only currently to get thoughts on whether they're worth adding or not - Currently "Largest 2" is the longest execution time out of any test/validator, for me, at 1.3s-1.6s, the other two are ~0.3 and ~0.7

You may also modify the code to verify subsequent turns' time limit to be sure that things are set correctly.

The three new validators - @Timinator, any thoughts?
@Harry.B. Do you have an example of what you meant by "blockers - breakable blocks - already drawn connections"? A visual example would be even better. Thanks.

Crude examples: https://imgur.com/a/u9ejqM7

Already drawn paths are exactly as described - The solution would need to navigate from a start tile, to the drawn path (if applicable) then to the other starting tile.

Blockers are just tiles that can't be used - Could allow for larger grids but essentially doesn't change much.

Breakable/destructible blocks can be broken then that tile can be used in a path. If you break both, in the example, there is no valid solution but breaking only one allows for a valid solution.

I love the 3 new validators. I'm pretty sure I could go even larger as long as the grids were not sparse.

For these 3 new validators, my times (Python) are:

Largest 1 - < 0.20 sec
Largest 2 - ~0.25 sec
Largest 3 - ~0.60 sec

My timing issues are with the sparse grids. My slowest test and validator are:

Larger Sparse 3 - ~1.85 sec
Larger Sparse 3 (validator) - ~1.5 sec

Are your times in Python? I find the sparse grids very difficult to solve in Python considering the time limit.

Mine is Python, yeah. 

Interesting... My Larger Sparse 3 is 0.00s but your time for Largest 2 is drastically better than mine. I suppose it comes down to whatever heuristic you've chosen and the order of your search (i.e. NESW).

I'm assuming you did not need to alter your code to pass the new 3 tests?

No, no changes to my code to pass the three new validators. I do pretty significant logical optimization before using my heuristics. Most of that logic has to do with conflicts between two paths. When the grid is sparse, there are smaller numbers of potential conflicts. The three new validators are bigger, but they are not sparse, so there are lots of potential conflicts that can be found and exploited.

For the 3 new cases, here is how much time I spend backtracking on each case. The rest of the time is spent generating possible paths for each pair of endpoints.

Largest 1 - ~0.011 sec
Largest 2 - ~0.005 sec
Largest 3 - ~0.025 sec

How hard are the test cases to create? If they are easy, could you throw out a couple of 9x9 or 10x10 cases just for experimentation? Of course, they cannot be sparse or I will have no chance!
I'm NWES. I switched to NESW and saw little difference. The only thing is that my heuristics don't work on one of the sparse test cases now. I'll have to look at it later.

Thanks Timinator.

@Harry.B. Are there any grids where a different search order works noticeably better, but NESW performs poorly?
If yes, I'd definitely like those grids included in the cases if they aren't there yet.
If not, then *either* the search order doesnâ€™t matter, *or* we need to generate new cases to uncover such grids ðŸ˜‰
To be clear, my view is that the cases should *not* favour any search order.

* "already drawn paths" - I think it would reduce difficulty but again would allow for larger grids which may or may not make it harder. In my head it's a 50/50 whether it effects it or not.

* My search is SENW which passes but failed the new 3 with any other search order...
** I've now added extra optimizations on top of the standard brute-force code I had and now all pass (only tested the 3 new tests) regardless of directions but some search orders were slower. That being said, that is using the same directions regardless of the situation, you could change it and give prioritiy to directions pathing closer to the other colour tile which probably would be better anyway.
*** Naturally with this type of problem I think the order will matter anyways, if we're dealing with a colour tile near the bottom left and the other is top right SWNE will be slower finding a solution than NESW (assuming dfs)

@Timinator
Regarding the larger tests - I just make them manually by filling a ?x? square and removing the middle bits... The issue may be that since there are only 9 colours a 9x9 and 10x10 will have a fair few empty tiles but I'll make some anyways and see the outcome... (I also could include another colour with 0 which would help populate a larger grid)

> Naturally with this type of problem I think the order will matter anyways, if we're dealing with a colour tile near the bottom left and the other is top right SWNE will be slower finding a solution than NESW (assuming dfs)

Sure, but that's more of a situational effect. My point is that a player shouldn't have to rely on one specific search order to succeed in all cases. For instance, why should SENW be the "winning" order rather than any other? That feels arbitrary and illogical. If a solution works with SENW, it should also work with NWSE, or any other order. If it doesn't, that could be a sign of unintended bias in the case design. I'd be surprised if the original Numberlink puzzle favoured any particular search order. If it does, someone ought to publish a research paper on it! ðŸ˜†

By the way, I've found this link which details how one website designs their Numberlink puzzles: https://puzzlemadness.co.uk/howwemakenumberlink/

I am now finding 100% of possible paths + still a few that are not possible. It takes time to pull all the weeds, so I don't think it is worth it to pull the rest. Because I am finding 100% of possible paths, I don't think search order matters for me. I have tried 12 of the 24 possible search orders and I have no issues and little time variance. I will send a PM to the two of you with a little bit of data I gathered that will format nicer in the forum.

The only heuristic I use is when I decide which paths go through to Algorithm X and which paths are discarded.
I can solve all test cases except #39: Larger Sparse 3 (validator) with zero heuristics. I have not made any changes recently. I just didn't think to try without my heuristic.

1. Does "zero heuristics" mean all paths are fed to the Algorithm X solver without any logical reduction?

2. How about #19: Larger Sparse 3 (test)? Is it the most time-consuming case? If so, is it because it has the greatest total number of paths?

"zero heuristics" means *only* logic is used when enumerating and reducing the number of possible paths between each pair of endpoints. After logical-problem-space reduction, all remaining paths are fed to Algorithm X.

Yes, #19 is the most time-consuming. An additional 300 ms or so is needed for Algorithm X setup and search compared to when I use the heuristic. It is due to a big grid and a small number of endpoint pairs which results in a lot of paths.

I'm not surprised at all to see Timinator on this puzzle, Algorithm X is the first thing that came to my mind to solve it.
I ended up changing my approach a couple of times and did not use Algorithm X to solve it in the end.
This is a great puzzle, good job to the author, will approve.

Thanks ðŸ™‚

* Added 3 new tests "Largest 1-3" to go with the validators.
I can't see any new tests/validators named "Longest".

My bad - Meant "Largest 1-3"...

Also could I ask your general thoughts on difficulty rating?
I think one of the comment mentioned that it used to be medium, it definitely too hard for medium, hard is the right one in my opinion.

@cedricdd
Just letting you know there are 3 new tests and validators - "Rectangular 1-3".
Increasing the max size from 10 to 20.

(This should be the final addition ðŸ˜€)

Everything looks good.
I guess you won't be adding very big ones like 15x15 or 20x20, you could aim for "very hard" difficulty but it might never get approved :D
There is a planned part 3 - I may include 0-9 and a-? for colours so could allow for larger grids. Unlikely to be "Very Hard" as I'd probably not be able to solve it myself ðŸ˜‚

No problem ðŸ˜‰

Here are two minor updates and some feedback on your answers.

Rules
* Consider using the plural form of "coordinate" (twice).

* Please change (w, h) to (w - 1, h - 1).

Question on time limit
* "wondering how I work out a good rule for setting a single time limit for all": I'm wondering the same. My personal view is that the time limit should be based on the execution time of the most commonly used "slower" languages on the platform (Python and PHP, I guess?), with a small buffer added.

What are the longest execution times (after reading the inputs) you've seen for your Python and Java solutions so far?

Question on turn limit
* I can't see the point of forcing the player to have at least 1 path longer than 2 tiles.

In effect, the maximum number of turns is always h * w - (no. of start_tiles / 2), since it's impossible not to exceed that without triggering an error. So, it seems reasonable to just define that as the general upper bound, which you've set as 50 (and that fits particularly well if you plan to have 7x7 cases).

Question on viewer behaviour for invalid path
* I think it's clearer if the viewer shows an invalid path when applicable. Also, I'd prefer that only the tiles in the invalid path turn red, rather than the entire grid.

Thanks.

* Minor points updated.

* Exec time - I will do some testing and find out.

* Invalid paths - Changed to as you suggested.

Thanks!

Seems general <125ms at the moment, certainly a lot less than the current limit...

I'll be testing with sparse puzzles to see what sort of range they're getting - Generally seems anything with 7 height or width will need at least 5 starting nodes which essentially makes it a sparse 6x6. (Added a test at the end that works locally but timeout once uploaded)

Just to clarify a few things:

a) Is that timing just for the first turn?

b) Have you generated the full solution before sending the first output?

c) Are the timings similar for both Python and Java?

Thanks.

New values with the new testing validator:

Python for Large 3 Validator (The new second one) - which is the longest so far for python:
Timing after imports, just before first input to final output: 4.3s
Timing from after first input to final output - 870ms
This is after I added a sort of 'janky' assumption / optimization that a valid solution will be available with only generating X paths from start tile to start tile
instead of all 650,000 paths. Without the optimization it's 13s locally...

Java for Large 3 Validator (The new second one) - 
Timing from after first input to final output - 900ms (without the janky optim)

* Yes, generating the full solution before sending first output.

* The python version is slightly slower than the java version for all but the last test.

It seems like the first turn time limit could be reduced to 1 to 2 seconds, depending on whether you plan to add more complex cases. Maybe lower it first and see how others respond to the shorter time?

Also, could you update "<var>w-1</var>" to either "<var>w</var>-1" or "<var>w</var><const>-1</const>"? The same applies to "h-1".

Thanks.

I'll slap it in the middle for now, I will likely involve some more test but if they're larger they will likely be dense so won't be above 1-2s (I think ðŸ¥´). - The tests/validators for the most part are just randomly placed for now, with a few exceptions, so I'll probably reorder or alter slightly.

Will do, I believe I saw <var>width-1</var> in an official puzzle which is why I put it like that, but I don't remember which...

Yes, even the creators at CG often misapply formatting in my opinion ðŸ™ƒ

I suggested not to format the whole expression (w-1 / h-1) because "w" and "h" are variable names, whereas "-1" isn't.

I just noticed that you updated the statement and added the illustrative example. It looks clear and well done!

Constraints
* Consider changing "turn outputs" to "subsequent outputs" for clarity.

* It may be a good idea to specify as a constraint the range of number of colours in the cases.

Cases
* A few cases are designated as both a test and a validator. Apart from "All Colours Test" 1 and 2 where this dual designation can be easily justified, are the other designations likely to change?

Thanks.

* Added the two constraint changes (Not uploaded update yet)

* Yes, I still need to do the validators for those that are marked as both - I've just not got around to doing it.

Updated version now uploaded.

New validators:
Medium 3
Medium 4
Medium 5
Slightly Larger 1
Larger Sparse 1

Cases
* Single Path (test): This case violates the first constraint.

* Single Path (validator): Same comment as above.

* Single Colour (test): The grid in test27.json contains 6 lines while h = 5. (This discrepancy may not affect execution, I guess? It should still be fixed anyway.)

* Single Colour (test): Running the following line caused the game to crash (likely affects all test cases):
print("3 3 4 1 7")

The game has crashed. Please contact the author and enclose the following error:

[edit: I removed the error since it widened the comment area too much and you've fixed the error already]

* Single Colour (test): I ran the following code but the game didn't detect "1 0 1 3 7" as wrong:

h, w = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for i in range(h):
    row = input()

print("0 0 0 4 7")
print("0 4 4 4 7")
print("4 1 4 4 7")
print("3 1 4 1 7")
print("1 0 4 0 7")
print("1 2 2 2 7")
print("1 1 2 1 7")
print("1 3 3 3 7")
print("1 0 1 3 7")
print("2 0 2 3 7")
print("3 0 3 3 7")

Viewer
* Single Colour (test): Very minor issue. I ran the following code and passed the case, though it looked a bit odd to have the last segment added *after* the whole grid turned green (likely affects all test cases):

h, w = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for i in range(h):
    row = input()

print("0 0 0 4 7")
print("0 4 4 4 7")
print("4 1 4 4 7")
print("3 1 4 1 7")
print("1 0 4 0 7")
print("1 2 2 2 7")
print("1 1 2 1 7")
print("1 3 3 3 7")
print("1 0 1 1 7")
print("1 2 1 3 7")
print("2 1 2 2 7")
print("3 1 3 3 7")

* (Optional) Consider adding tooltips to display cell coordinates when hovering over the grid. This would be a nice quality-of-life improvement.

Thanks.

P.S. I can't remember how I originally found the source code, but it's much easier for me to review the cases directly through the json files. Hope that's ok with you.

* Fixed the constraint to <= 1
* Fixed the crash issue
* Invalid path: I believe that should be an easy fix (I hope...) (edit: It was)
^ (edit: now updated)

* Yeah... I use js to for the cascading green/red tiles (to update throughout the frame) but just the graphicEntityModule for the connectors (which I assume updates at the end of the frame) - I suppose switching the connectors to js could work - It's a minor issue but actually quite a big fix unfortunately... I will look into it after sorting everything else.

* Tooltips: I will look into it.

* Yeah that's fine - I haven't added source code here yet because the code is an absolute bloodbath...

Thanks as always!

Great!

Now the only remaining points from me are those related to the viewer (1. green/red tiles in the last game turn, 2. optional tooltips).

For the tooltips, I'd also like to suggest displaying the colour identifiers along with the coordinates. These would apply to all cells and could show the following possible values:

â€¢ None: for empty cells

â€¢ The colour identifier: for cells that are initially coloured and/or where single-coloured segments have been placed

â€¢ Multiple colour identifiers, or Error (?): for cells where the player attempts to use an invalid colour identifier or connects the same cell with segments of different colour identifiers

I could further suggest that the tooltips could also include "connected to" information, but that might be a bit too much and not particularly helpful for players.

Thanks!

Turns out the viewer issue 1 was actually quite easy - Found graphicEntityModule.commitEntityState(0,sprite) in the docs which is perfect and updates it at the start of the frame.

Tooltips on the other hand seem to be incompatible out of the box with the group/viewport module. Suppose the options are to remove the viewport or to find some work around. I'll have a look at a work around first though.

That's great to hear!

I have limited experience with CG SDK, so I'm not sure what would work best here, but could the TooltipModule ( https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/25775/codingame-sdk-documentation/tooltip-module ) be helpful in this case?

That's the one I'm attempting to use, however, it seems the viewport 'clickable' is over the top of the the tiles / takes precedence .
